title: Meta-Learning: Learn How to Learn
description: Master evidence-based learning techniques: spaced repetition, deliberative practice, procedural learning, and active recall.

steps.title: What is Meta-Learning?
steps.description: Introduction to learning how to learn.

conceptCard.title: Learning how to learn is the most valuable skill
conceptCard.body: Once you master meta-learning, you can learn anything faster and more effectively.

conceptCard.title: Memory is a process, not a storage
conceptCard.body: Memory gets stronger through retrieval practice, spacing, and elaboration - not just exposure.

steps.title: Spaced Repetition
steps.description: Create a spaced repetition schedule for learning a concept.

steps.title: Deliberative Practice
steps.description: Learn how experts get better through focused practice.

conceptCard.title: Deliberative practice beats passive learning
conceptCard.body: Focused practice with feedback at the edge of your ability creates expertise faster than time alone.

steps.title: Practice Deliberative Practice
steps.description: Design a deliberative practice session for a skill.

steps.title: Procedural Learning
steps.description: Learn how skills become automatic through practice.

conceptCard.title: Procedures become automatic through practice
conceptCard.body: You can't learn to type by reading about typing - you have to type. Practice creates automaticity.

steps.title: Active Recall
steps.description: Learn why testing yourself strengthens memory more than re-reading.

conceptCard.title: Recall strengthens memory more than re-reading
conceptCard.body: The struggle to retrieve information is what strengthens memory. Easy learning feels productive but doesn't stick.

steps.title: Practice Active Recall
steps.description: Create active recall questions for a topic.

steps.title: Build Your Learning System
steps.description: Submit a learning system plan using techniques learned (optional).

steps.title: Knowledge Check
steps.description: Test your understanding of meta-learning principles.

questions.question: What is the main principle of spaced repetition?
questions.explanation: Spaced repetition works by reviewing information at increasing intervals (1 day, 3 days, 1 week, etc.)

questions.question: What makes deliberative practice different from regular practice?
options: It's focused on specific weaknesses with feedback
questions.correctAnswer: It's focused on specific weaknesses with feedback
questions.explanation: Deliberative practice is goal-oriented, focused, and includes immediate feedback.

questions.question: True or False: Re-reading notes is more effective than testing yourself.
questions.explanation: Active recall (testing yourself) is more effective than passive re-reading, even though it feels harder.

questions.question: What happens to information in the first hour after learning (according to the forgetting curve)?
questions.explanation: The forgetting curve shows rapid initial forgetting - about 50% in the first hour.

questions.question: What is procedural learning?
options: Learning "how to do" something that becomes automatic
questions.correctAnswer: Learning "how to do" something that becomes automatic
questions.explanation: Procedural learning is about skills that become automatic through practice (like typing or riding a bike).

questions.question: Why is active recall more effective than re-reading?
options: The struggle to retrieve strengthens memory
questions.correctAnswer: The struggle to retrieve strengthens memory
questions.explanation: The difficulty of retrieving information from memory is what strengthens the memory pathway.

questions.question: What is the testing effect?
questions.explanation: The testing effect shows that testing yourself doesn't just measure learning - it actually creates learning.

questions.question: What should you focus on during deliberative practice?
options: Tasks at the edge of your ability
questions.correctAnswer: Tasks at the edge of your ability
questions.explanation: Deliberative practice requires pushing beyond your comfort zone to the edge of your ability.

badge.name: Meta-Learner
badge.description: Completed the Meta-Learning track and demonstrated understanding of spaced repetition, deliberative practice, procedural learning, and active recall.
